title: Searching for objects driven by context

author: Bogdan Alexe, Department of Information Technology and Electrical Engineering, ETH Zurich

segmentation: The dominant visual search paradigm for object detection is sliding windows.
A classifier is trained.
To decide whether a window contains an instance of a target class, and then it is used at Test time to score all windows in a test image on a regular grid in location and scale.
The local maximum of the Korean windows are internal return as detections.
Despite being very simple.
And effective, the sliding windows paradigm seems also to be unnatural and very wasteful.
For example, in a typical image it evaluates 10s of thousands of windows.
Now in our paper.
We propose to learn strategies that detects objects which intelligently.
Explored the space of all windows in in a test image.
By making sequentials.
Or observation at locations which are decided based on on previous ones.
Dallas Strategies exploited the statistical relation between the appearance of a window.
And the relative position with the ground truth object as observed in the training set.
Here we show the key idea of our approach.
By applying an ideal strategy to search for a car in a test image, we might start at Windows W 1, which is a Patch of Sky.
And as we learn in the training set, the cars are usually below the Sky, so we decide to go from Windows W 1 below to window W2, Windows WW2.
It covers a Patch of road and from the training set we do know that cars are usually found on roads.
So we decide to keep searching the road region moving to window W3 window W3 covers the right end of a car, so we decide to move left to window W4 which.
Complete the search.

Our method that detects object by by sequential process evaluating one window at each time step given the current window in the test image, our method first find training windows similarly in position and appearance.
Then each such training Windows vote for a possible object location to the to the displacement vector, and then each each of these votes will is.
Transferred to the test image by applying the displacement vector to the current observation window at each time step.
All the votes are accumulated into into into our probabilistic map, and this.
And each of these Maps, they are integrated overtime such that they will decide which window to evaluate next.
Now.
We evaluate our method on the state of the art of UC Pascal 10 datasets.
Here we show results for the deformable part model of felt involved.
Our method evaluates two order of magnitude fewer windows.

And more more more specific, our method evaluates just one 100 Windows as opposed to the 10s of thousands windows evaluated by the sliding window Windows method at the same time our method maintains the.
The detection performance and also surpass it as we do use the entire information called collected of the of the entire image.

Our method is general and it can be applied on top of any object detector because it doesn't make any assumptions about it, its form and we prove this at our poster showing results for another state of the art, the Windows classifier and intersection kernel, SVM for back and forth on surface features.
We are looking forward to showing you further results of our method at poster 80 on Thursday.
Thank you.
